column1: Szczecinek (Polish pronunciation: [ʂt͡ʂɛˈt͡ɕinɛk] Shche-tsee-nek; German: Neustettin; Kashubian: Nowé Sztetëno) is a historic city in Middle Pomerania
column3: with a population of more than 40
column5: it has been the capital of Szczecinek County in the West Pomeranian Voivodeship since 1999. It is also known as Krono-Zdrój or Kronobyl. It is an important railroad junction
column6: located along the main Poznań - Kolobrzeg line
column7: which crosses less important lines to Chojnice and Słupsk. The city boundaries were expanded in 2009 to include the surrounding villages of Świątki and Trzesieka
column8: a total area of 48.63 square kilometres (18.78 square miles).

column1: The turbulent history of Szczecinek reaches back to the High Middle Ages
column2: when the area was ruled by Pomeranian dukes and princes. The majority of the city's architecture survived World War II and
column4: its entire Old Town was proclaimed a national heritage monument of Poland.

column1: Szczecinek lies in eastern part of West Pomeranian Voivodeship. Historically
column2: it was included within Western Pomerania. In 2010
column3: the city boundaries were expanded as the town merged with the following villages in Gmina Szczecinek: Gałowo

column1: In the Middle Ages a Slavic stronghold existed in present-day Szczecinek. It was part of the early Polish state in the 10th century
column2: and as a result of the 12th-century fragmentation of Poland
column3: it became part of the separate Duchy of Pomerania.

column2: the castle at the site of a former stronghold
column3: and town were founded under Lübeck law by Duke Wartislaw IV of Pomerania and modelled after Szczecin (German: Stettin) which is situated about 150 kilometres (93 miles) to the west. The initial name was "Neustettin" (Polish: Nowy Szczecin
column5: Latin: Stetin Nova). It was also known as "Klein Stettin" (Polish: Mały Szczecin
column6: German: Klein Stettin). In 1707 the town was known in Polish as Nowoszczecin
column7: while the Mały Szczecin name gradually developed into the modern name Szczecinek.The town was fortified to face the Brandenburgers
column8: with a wall and palisades. In 1356 it was hit by the plague. Thankful for their survival
column10: Barnim IV and Wartislaw V founded the Augustine monastery Marientron
column11: on the Marientron hill on the southern bank of the Trzesiecko Lake. It was plundered by Brandenburgers in 1470. From 1368 to 1390 it was the seat of an eponymous duchy under its only historic ruler Wartislaw V. Afterwards
column12: it was ruled by Pomeranian duchies: Darłowo (Rügenwalde) (-1418)
column13: Wolgast (-1474) and the united Duchy of Pomerania (until 1618).

column8: looted and burned by Polish troops and Tatars because King Casimir IV Jagiellon wanted to take revenge on Eric II of Pomerania who supported the Teutonic Knights.In 1601 a Polish school was established

column10: which as today's I Liceum Ogólnokształcące is one of the oldest high schools in Pomerania. During the Thirty Years' War it was captured and plundered by the Swedes and Austrians. After the war

column17: great-grandfather of TV presenter Jerry Springer and a prominent member of the town's Jewish community launched an unsuccessful attempt to sue agitator Dr Ernst Henrici
column18: claiming that an inflammatory anti-semitic speech in the town led directly to the burning down of the synagogue on 18 February of that year.

column1: In 1914 the Regional Museum was established. In 1923 the Catholic Church of the Holy Spirit was built
column3: as it was co-financed by local Poles.After the Nazis took power in Germany in the 1930s
column5: and the invasion of Poland was carried out from the town at the beginning of World War II in 1939. In September 1944
column6: the Germans made the first arrests of local members of the Polish underground organization "Odra"
column7: ultimately crushing it in the following weeks. The town was captured by the Red Army in February 1945
column8: and put under Polish administration. The town's German population was expelled
column9: and it was repopulated with Poles
